H0.text: Which British prime Minister wrote two novels 'Coningsby' and 'Sybil' in the 1840s. Robert Peel

H1.text: Which British prime Minister wrote two novels 'Coningsby' and 'Sybil' in the 1840s. William Gladstone

H2.text: Which British prime Minister wrote two novels 'Coningsby' and 'Sybil' in the 1840s. Lord Palmerston

H3.text: Which British prime Minister wrote two novels 'Coningsby' and 'Sybil' in the 1840s. Disraeli

A4.text: In the 1840s Disraeli wrote a trilogy of novels with political themes. Coningsby attacks the evils of the Whig Reform Bill of 1832 and castigates the leaderless conservatives for not responding. Sybil; or, The Two Nations (1845) reveals Peel's betrayal over the Corn Laws.

A5.text: Disraeli's novels are his main literary achievement. These themes are expanded in Tancred (1847). With Coningsby; or, The New Generation (1844), Disraeli, in Blake's view...

A7.text: Benjamin Disraeli wrote the novel Sybil in 1845.
